text: I think it would help if you said which of the two bit patterns you expected, and made explicit which one was emulated (I'm assuming the `bootstrap run` one?). Fun story for sure.

elements.text: I think it would help if you said which of the two bit patterns you expected, and made explicit which one was emulated (I'm assuming the `bootstrap run` one?). Fun story for sure.

text: Hi Hamish, just FYI, I often upload my videos as unlisted to YouTube, and they are 4K.  There are only 2 issues I've seen; firstly that it takes a lot longer for them to 'prepare' the HD version, and you get low res until it is processed.  Secondly, the first few seconds of viewing are blurred.  As far as I can tell this is just normal behavior.  Thinking about it, I wonder if this is due to me being a premium subscriber (I haven't looked back since turning that on and turning adverts off :wink:

attachments.text: This interactive visual tool lets you see how accessible your color palettes are to viewers who are colorblind.

text: The blurry image at the start could be because you've set it to auto on the resolution, so it's optimising for the discovered connection speed. Could try setting to the top resolution before playing?

elements.text: The blurry image at the start could be because you've set it to auto on the resolution, so it's optimising for the discovered connection speed. Could try setting to the top resolution before playing?

text: Hi Duncan, yes, i think that works, but it puts the onus on the viewer.  I can't find a setting to select the default playback res.

elements.text: Hi Duncan, yes, i think that works, but it puts the onus on the viewer.  I can't find a setting to select the default playback res.
There isn't one.

text: Well the "default" is to try and get the resolution you uploaded I presume

elements.text: Well the "default" is to try and get the resolution you uploaded I presume

text: Hmm, I’m not sure I totally understand your crisis of faith, but I have thoughts. Making a visual system as powerful as possible is a hard problem. To me is sounds like you are trying to make this an entirely visual interface without any symbolic formalism behind it? That would be crazy to pull off! I think it’s possible to include symbols, but to minimize their use as much as possible and get something both visual and powerful from it.

elements.text: Hmm, I’m not sure I totally understand your crisis of faith, but I have thoughts. Making a visual system as powerful as possible is a hard problem. To me is sounds like you are trying to make this an entirely visual interface without any symbolic formalism behind it? That would be crazy to pull off! I think it’s possible to include symbols, but to minimize their use as much as possible and get something both visual and powerful from it.

text:
This is amazing stuff! I love the way in which the changes are propagated throughout the system and there are snapshots of each result on the border. One thing I wanted to ask was whether you have considered making the operations as a first class item in the language, that is, sometime when you are in a remix mode, you might want to move/swap around the operators themselves between the operands of another combination that will yield an unforeseen happenstance combination. I think such a structuring of the system could potentially lead to opening up the space for more creative operations.

I really love the direction and would love to see how this evolves. Great job!

elements.text:

I think such a structuring of the system could potentially lead to opening up the space for more creative operations.

I really love the direction and would love to see how this evolves. Great job!

text:
Another idea is to have operations to swap around the operands themselves, so like in the cases where commutativity doesn’t hold, you can swap a • b to b • a.

Also, how about decomposition a la projection, that is, you can decompose a bivector into two vectors? (I guess some of these operations would be surjective and you might need to present the user with an option panel on how to decompose).

I think there are so many possibilities in here to experiment and I’m sure you might have thought about the possibilities through in here better than me. So I think it might also hepl having a focus on a core subset that fulfills the need of content creators who want to build pretty 3D visualization would be a great niche to try this out with. Have you started looking for such an audience for this yet?

So I think it might also hepl having a focus on a core subset that fulfills the need of content creators who want to build pretty 3D visualization would be a great niche to try this out with. Have you started looking for such an audience for this yet?

text:
<@UFPRPSA4S> I'm quite "immoderate", certainly for now :smile: symbolism is a "last resort". Algebra had its "never use visualization" zealots: Bourbaki, Djikstra, Legrange, it seems only fair to have a "never use visualization" zealot.
You can hear more about my (possibly dumb) reasons for this here <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xrDZ--AuiL8> and, in case you've not seen it, in the <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hR-MQm3c13Q|presentation on this project>, especially the parts about live coding and programming by diagram.
In the back of my mind, I have a simulation of all of the many smart people who have, over the years, told me "visualization is good but it has limits". I've already made what feel like concessions :sweat_smile: and my simulation (and the real people...) will say "I told you so" at some point.
I should stop now but I've got some notes on this for a talk at some point.

and my simulation (and the real people...) will say "I told you so" at some point.
I should stop now but I've got some notes on this for a talk at some point.

text: <@UDKTZSD6H> I'm not sure I understand what you mean by "remix mode" or first class operations? I've been wanting to make something where you make your own functions of course :sweat_smile: it is a bit of an embarrassment I didn't have that. I've also been wanting to implement a "simplify this algebra" system (partly because... previously... it's been about learning GA...), but the idea of that is to turn your code into something that produces the same output, not a different one!

elements.text: I'm not sure I understand what you mean by "remix mode" or first class operations? I've been wanting to make something where you make your own functions of course

text: With a * b -> b * a, you can just do that the normal text editing way and I am fine keeping it like that ;D

elements.text: With a * b -> b * a, you can just do that the normal text editing way and I am fine keeping it like that ;D

text: In terms of audience I've been thinking primarily two things: people with no technical background (either teenagers or maybe 3D artists at game companies) and people wanting to learn 3D math for engineering/physics on youtube.

elements.text: In terms of audience I've been thinking primarily two things: people with no technical background (either teenagers or maybe 3D artists at game companies) and people wanting to learn 3D math for engineering/physics on youtube.

text:
<@U017GNJM021> Think drag and drop on operators, operands, and values. Just like how you can select some text and then drag and drop it to rearrange the text, if you make + and * a block like the operands, they would be amenable for drag and drop too. Say you drag a + from a certain operation and then drop it to an operation where there is a division and you will get to interactively explore what such things result in.

I recommend such an interaction under the notion that to pan around on the canvas, users might already reach out for their mouse. So letting some tinkering with the mouse available might also be helpful.

elements.text:

Say you drag a + from a certain operation and then drop it to an operation where there is a division and you will get to interactively explore what such things result in.

I recommend such an interaction under the notion that to pan around on the canvas, users might already reach out for their mouse. So letting some tinkering with the mouse available might also be helpful.

text: <@U017GNJM021> That looks like a neat target market. I think kids would love this and also if you somehow map back or inline the equations (as a toggle-able mode), it would make it a great educational value to people who want to explore and learn GA (something like say: <http://immersivemath.com|immersivemath.com>). They will get a chance to see what the interactions of these elements are like and map that back to the symbol runes they see in their texts.

elements.text: That looks like a neat target market. I think kids would love this and also if you somehow map back or inline the equations (as a toggle-able mode), it would make it a great educational value to people who want to explore and learn GA (something like say:

text:
Gotcha. First I'll say that I do like Bret Victor, and a lot of this is inspired by his work. It's clearly an embarrassment that, for a programmer to specify a vector, often all they can do is write eg vec2(2.9,4.4), when clearly that should be specified with the mouse (and a transform/dual quaternion should be specified with a VR controller!). The same is true of a function curve.

However, I agree with the criticism many have of Bret Victor/GRAIL/MaxMSP-style visual programming that they use mouse/drag-and-drop too much. The problem of "choose what the program does" almost always means "scroll to this point in execution, choose a function and some variables, and apply that". That is best done with a keyboard that impacts a carat. The number of variables and functions available to you is large enough that if you try to pick them from a menu, it'll take much longer than typing the name, and you'll be more likely to click the wrong thing.

I've considered having "click on this variable in the display window and its name is pasted at your carat", which is partway towards drag and drop. But I've never felt the need for that while using the system, so I might never implement that!

Indeed for the purpose you describe I was thinking about a toggle-able "just show me the names" mode. It might turn out to be unnecessary though!
